data.title: Road to Joy

data.text:
(compiled August 8, 2011)

You can download all of the songs on the playlist from box.com account if you CLICK HERE:

https://app.box.com/s/r6q845ocgcxx6kjj912yhhmabhy2gxev

(â€¦and you should put it in the order of the actual playlist if you have timeâ€¦there definitely is an intentional flow to it!)

Spotify playlist (not all tracks show upâ€¦see full list below):

*

Road to Joyâ€“ Bright Eyes

Hawaiian Airâ€“ Friendly Fires

Fuel Upâ€“ Stornoway

Techno Fanâ€“ The Wombats

Fiyaâ€“ tUnE-yArDs

Georges Street/The Tatar Frigateâ€“ Rodrigo y Gabriela

You can come to meâ€“ The Helio Sequence

Revival (Sidecar Tommy remix)â€“ Beats Antique

Possibly Maybeâ€“ Bjork

Chop and changeâ€“ The Black Keys

I Suppose I should say â€˜thanksâ€™ or some shitâ€“ Gold Panda

Night Busâ€“ Lucy Rose

Race outâ€“ Battles

Hot Knivesâ€“ Bright Eyes

As far as I can seeâ€“ Phantogram

Wasteâ€“ Foster The People

Creating cyclical headachesâ€“ Prefuse 73 (with Four Tet)

Heavy in Your Arms- Florence and the Machine

Shake me downâ€“ Cage the Elephant

Wisdom of Antiquityâ€“ Break Science

*****************************************************************************************************************

â€˜Road to Joyâ€™ (by Bright Eyes) was a very fitting song to start this new playlist off with. It was the perfect WAKE UP call that I needed to get out of my lilâ€™ rut last month. I really dig its recognizable â€˜Ode to Joyâ€™ melody and its sarcastic lyrics strung throughout (that seem to be a parody of the â€œAmerican Dreamâ€):

â€œThe sun came up with no conclusion

Flowers sleeping in their beds

This cityâ€™s cemeteryâ€™s humming

Iâ€™m wide-awake, itâ€™s morning

I have my drugs, I have my woman

They keep away my loneliness

My parents have they have their religion

But sleep in separate housesâ€¦. (love this line)

I read the body count out of the paper

And now itâ€™s written all over my face

No one ever plans to sleep out in the gutter

Sometimes thatâ€™s just the most comfortable place!â€¦

So Iâ€™m drinking, breathing, writing, singing (for the â€œPursuit of Happinessâ€â€¦)

Everyday Iâ€™m on the clock

My mind races with all my longings

But cant keep up with what I gotâ€¦.

I hope I donâ€™t sound too ungrateful

What history gave modern man

A telephone to talk to strangers

Machine guns and a camera lensâ€¦

So when youâ€™re asked to fight a war thatâ€™s over nothing

Itâ€™s best to join the side thatâ€™s gonna win (Many would agree with thatâ€¦)

And no oneâ€™s sure how all of this got started

But weâ€™re gonna make them goddam certain how its gonna end

Oh ya we will, oh ya we will!

(And now it becomes very obvious that the singer disagrees with the so-called â€œAmerican Dreamâ€ and that he thinks itâ€™s a misleading, superficial version of something much more raw and REAL.)

Well I could have been a famous singer

If I had someone elseâ€™s voice

But failureâ€™s always sounded better

Lets F*CK it up boys, MAKE SOME NOISE! (These last two lines always make me wanna throw my hands up in the air and SHOUT REAL LOUD!â€¦not that being loud is hard for ME to doâ€¦)

â€˜Hot Knivesâ€™ was the other Bright Eyes song that I was immediately drawn to. My favorite parts of the song are: â€œWhen I do wrong, I am with Godâ€¦she thought!â€ and â€œWhen I feel lost, I am notâ€¦at all!â€ So tricky and coyâ€¦LOVE IT! The other part I love (even though kind of crude) is: â€œOh, Iâ€™ve made love, yeah, Iâ€™ve been fuckedâ€¦so what?!â€ Two other lines that really stuck out to me were: â€œIâ€™m a cartoon, youâ€™re a full moonâ€¦letâ€™s stay up!â€ and â€œShe just vanishedâ€¦into a thick mist of change!â€ (clever way to describe it)

â€˜Hawaiian Airâ€™ is a song that was recommended to me by my friend, Nicole DeJesus. When I first listened to it, I kinda found the intro â€œboppingâ€ sound to be somewhat annoying. BUT, as I listened on, I started to enjoy its light and carefree vibe, and realized that its effervescent beat matched perfectly with the jittery butterflies that someone flying to Hawaii WOULD have. It then made me think of Andy Bluhm and Jason White, two of my buddies that were traveling to Hawaii this month. I havenâ€™t yet been to Hawaii, but Iâ€™ve hear itâ€™s AMAZING, especially Kauai. One dayâ€¦

My favorite parts of this song are at ~1:40 min in:

â€œTouchinâ€™ down

Hit the ground

Iâ€™m breathing new air

Can I take this all in?

Can I take this all in? (LOVE IT!)

(and)â€¦

Up in the sky Honolulu bound

Steel guitar and the melee sound

Did I give it all?

I guess I gave it all

Feeling the shapes keeps me reticent

Stuck in my seat from the turbulence

And if I fall

Then I fall (Such a good line- totally exudes that carefree attitude of vacation)

Friendly Fires are an English band from St Albans, Hertfordshire, England. They are currently signed to XL Recordings. Their self-titled debut album was released on 1 September 2008 and was announced as one of the shortlisted twelve for the 2009 Mercury Prize on 21 July 2009. They have toured extensively, with past performances taking place throughout the UK, Europe, Japan, USA, Canada, Mexico, South America and Australia.

â€˜Techno Fanâ€™ is a song by a band (The Wombats) that was recommended to me by my German friend, Lisa Pfisterer, who saw them at the 2011 LoveBox music festival in Vicotria Park, London. After listening to a few of their songs, I soon became addicted to â€˜Techno Fan.â€™ Aside from having a fun and contagious beat, its lyrics are amusing and tell a story that we can all relate to. Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ve all had a friend and/or acquaintance that made you feel like you were pulling teeth when you were trying to get them to have a good time. This song describes a person like that very well, and I love its rebellious attitude in trying to deal with them:

â€œShut up and move with me, move with me or, or get out of my face

I didnâ€™t queue for an hour to leave straight away

Shut up and stay with me, stay with me or, or let go of my hand

The lasers fill our minds with empty plansâ€

The Wombats are an indie rock band formed in Liverpool, England. The band comprises native Liverpudlians Matthew Murphy (lead vocals, guitar, nose harp, keyboard) and Dan Haggis (drums, percussion, keyboard and backing vocals), alongside Norwegian-born Tord Ã˜verland-Knudsen (bass guitar, guitar, keyboard and backing vocals). The band is signed to 14th Floor Records and Bright Antenna in the United States.

In April 2008, the band put out their first U.S. release on Bright Antenna, That summer, the band performed live at a number of major festivals, including Glastonbury Festival in June and T in the Park in July, and Reading and Leeds. In September 2010, the band announced they were near to completing their second studio album in the MRG Recording Studio in Los Angeles, California. The Wombats also played at the 2011 Southside and Hurricane music festivals in Germany, the latter of which Lisa Pfisterer also went to!

In describing their next album, Tord says, â€œYou take the electro and you take the grunge and you put it together with what we used to do on the first albumâ€¦then thatâ€™s what the albumâ€™s going to be.â€ Iâ€™m looking forward to it!

â€˜Fiyaâ€™ initially drew me in because of the soothing ukulele entrance, but then the beautiful lyrics to follow caught my attention even more:

â€œWhen a girl feels so alone

what a tease to throw a bone

shouldâ€™ve just stayed at home

when a girl feels so alone.â€

I love these next lyrics, and I think itâ€™s so cool how the picking of the ukulele gains intensity after the last line (in sync with her â€œbreathing out fireâ€ state of mind, I guess):

Whyâ€™d you think iâ€™d put out your fire?

whyâ€™d you think iâ€™d put out your fire?

donâ€™t you know i breathe in fire?

breathe out fire?

I also really like the line: â€œWhat happened between us makes sense if iâ€™m nothing, youâ€™re all nothingâ€¦f iâ€™m nothing at all.â€

BUT, my absolute FAVORITE part of the song kicks in at ~2:34 in, when she gracefully sings: â€œYou are always on my mindâ€ 4 times and then follows up these graceful vocals and graceful ukulele melody with an more aggressive and intense â€œWeâ€™re going outsideâ€¦?????â€ at ~3:10 in. The ukulele and percussion picks up with intensity EVEN MORE (~4 min in) as she bolts out her next line, which I donâ€™t think anyone can make out the words to. But thatâ€™s the cool part- You donâ€™t even need to know the words sheâ€™s shouting to understand the passion and frustration behind her voice. UNREAL. The last verse that follows this mysterious lilâ€™ shouting sesh is EVEN MORE mysterious in its words:

â€œI am not beautiful

i am not beautiful

i am unknown as the world goes underground (?)

and i am not beautiful

and i am not magic yet (?)

but i am in love at the end of the world (?)â€¦â€ (who knows?!!)

I thought that maybe I would have heard â€˜Fiyaâ€™ live when I saw tUnE-yArDs just recently at the Outside Lands music festival in San Francisco, but no; INSTEAD, I was ENTRALLED by the KICKASS SONGS on her NEWEST ALBUM, WhoKill. tUnE-yArDs was hands down the HIGHLIGHT of the weekend for me. One of the le siiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiickest live performances Iâ€™ve ever seen. SURREAL on so many levels. She kicked off her set with â€œDO YOU WANNA LIVE?!!â€, a song that is not on any of her albums but is CRUCIAL in getting people to STOP IN THEIR TRACKS and turn and DROP THEIR JAWS, wondering what the heck that MUSICAL MAGIC is on stage and who the heck is behind is. Yeah, sheâ€™s called tUnE-yArDs, and sheâ€™ll be TUNING YOUR EMOTIONS for the rest of your life. Iâ€™d since been telling people to pardon my uncontrollable urge to shout out â€œDO YOU WANNA LIVE?!!â€¦YEAH!â€ for the next few weeks, cause I will. It was THAT GOOD.

Standing only 4 ft from the stage (front and center) and I got some greats photos and videos (see my â€˜Siiiiiick snapshotsâ€™ and â€˜Live footageâ€™ page). I particularly like this photo below, because it pretty much sums up the ridiculously LARGE & GOOFY SMILE that I had on my face during the entire set. And I was STILL SMILING hours laterâ€¦

I just love her unique style and her incredibly raw talent in creating all sorts of crazy sounds from everyday items (glass bottle, microphone stand, etc.). It was absolutely UNREAL to see her create that magic from only a few feet away! Her looping of ukulele with vocals and percussion is like nothing Iâ€™ve ever heard before. She IS her OWN GENRE. Also, she clearly LOVE WHAT SHE DOES and it definitely comes through in her music. Itâ€™s one thing to see someone rocking outâ€¦but to see someone rocking out WEARING A SMILE?â€¦now thatâ€™s just CONTAGIOUS!

I WILL be seeing her AGAIN at the Regency Ballroom in San Francisco on November 23. The absolute BEST GIFT I could treat myself to on my birthday month. Next time, Iâ€™m coming with WARPAINT ON MY FACE!! (just like she had at Outside Landsâ€¦) ğŸ˜‰

â€˜You can come to meâ€™ is song from a band that was recommended to me by Nicole DeJesus (yet again). After listening to a few songs from their album, I was immediately drawn to â€˜You can come to meâ€™ because of the cool beats in beginningâ€¦they just made me happy. They lyrics arenâ€™t the best, but I do like the line: â€œYou can run, run, runâ€¦But you canâ€™t escape.â€ Simple, but it gets the point across. It also kind of hits home, since I very much try and run away (fugitive-style) when I find myself in a rut (simply cause I hate to bring others down). Funny, but true.

The Helio Sequence is a duo of sonic landscapers signed to label Sub Pop. Their music environments are optimistic and uplifting with a dash of psychedelic. The band was formed in 1999 in Beaverton, Oregon, a suburb of Portland, Oregon, and consists of Brandon Summers on Vocals/ Guitars and Benjamin Weikel on Drums/ Keyboards (who has also played for Modest Mouse on Drums). The band produces an eccentric brand of indie rock mixed with electronic elements. To date, they have released two albums on Sub Pop, two on the Portland-based label Cavity Search and a self-released EP. Their fourth album, entitled Keep Your Eyes Ahead, was released on January 29, 2008, by Sub Pop. The Helio Sequence toured with the British band Keane (who I also really like) through the U.S.A. and in June, 2010 they were Keaneâ€™s support act in several gigs through Great Britain during the British bandâ€™s Night Train Tour.

â€˜Revival (Sidecar Tommy remix)â€™ is a recent remix of a Beats Antique song that has been on their Blind Threshold album since 2010. Although the original â€˜Revivalâ€™ song is good, I actually prefer this Sidecar Tommy remix because of its aggressive wobble base components (~0:45) and the volatile fusion of sounds at ~1:21 and ~2:15 into the song. Definitely a great song for Zoe Jakes to belly dance toâ€¦and man, does she DO IT WELL. It was SO SIIIIIICK to see this incredible experimental world fusion and electronic music trio make their magic at Bonnaroo music festival this year. Jensyn Hyman and I definitely were LOST IN A TRANCE for a solid hour (and man, were my legs and hips sore thereafterâ€¦)

â€˜Possibly Maybeâ€™ is a song that I know very well because it used to be on the warm-up mix for a Modern Dance class that I took for â€œshits and gigglesâ€ my senior year at Bucknell University. My friend Tammy Ioanilli and I used to bite our lips and hold back laughter EVERY CLASS because this song (inappropriately sexual in itself) used to come on when we just HAPPENED to be in the most sexually suggestive yoga pose for warmup. The timing was always incredibly impeccable- EVERY TIME. What made the situation even MORE hilarious is that NO ONE else seemed to realize how sexual the lyrics of this song were but US! Um, HELLLLLLLO. Haha. We actually used to get a kick out of watching the uncomfortable mannerisms of the 4 boys in the class (including the one who we nicknamed â€œJessicaâ€), who HAD TO have felt awkward in a class full of 25 girls. SO MANY LAUGHSâ€¦EVERY CLASS.

Having listened to this song again, out of context of the class, Iâ€™ve actually come to appreciate how beautiful it is, even with its sexual lyrics:

â€œYour flirt finds me out

teases the crack in me

smittens me with hope

possibly maybe probably love

as much as i definitely enjoy solitude (My fav lines of the songâ€¦.SO GOOD)

i wouldnâ€™t mind perhaps

spending little time with you

sometimes

sometimes

possibly maybe probably love

uncertainty excites me

baby

who knows whatâ€™s going to happen?

lottery or car crash

or youâ€™ll join a cult

possibly maybe probably love

mon petit vulcan

youâ€™re eruptions and disasters

i keep calm

admiring your lava (Oh boyâ€¦)

i keep calm

possibly maybe probably love

since we broke up

iâ€™m using lipstick again

iâ€™ll suck my tongue (hahaâ€¦awesome)

as a remembrance of you.â€

The â€œpossibly maybe, probably loveâ€ is such cool little line that definitely sends a message of hopefulness, but yet â€œtease.â€ Lovely lilâ€™ balance.

BjÃ¶rk GuÃ°mundsdÃ³ttir is an Icelandic singer-songwriter, occasional actress, music composer and music producer, whose influential solo work includes eight solo albums and two original film soundtracks. Her eclectic musical style has achieved popular acknowledgement and popularity within many musical genres, such as rock, jazz, electronic dance music, classical and folk. Her voice has been acclaimed for its distinctive qualities, such as being ranked #8 on MTVâ€™s â€œ22 Greatest Voices in Musicâ€.

Also, in 2010, she received the Polar Music Prize from the Royal Swedish Academy of Music, in recognition for her â€œdeeply personal music and lyrics, her precise arrangements and her unique voiceâ€. (which is definitely apparent in her â€˜Possibly Maybeâ€™ songâ€¦)

â€˜Chop and Changeâ€™ is a song by The Black Keys that was featured on the soundtrack of The Twilight Saga: Eclipse movie. I donâ€™t watch those movies at all (and donâ€™t really watch tv for that matter), but I came across this song on YouTube when I was looking up some other artists (Bon Iver and St. Vincent) that also ended up being on this album. These Twilight movie soundtracks have a surprising number of stellar artists on them: Bon Iver, St. Vincent, Muse, The Black Keys, Florence & the Machine, The Strokes, Death Cab for Cutie, The Killers, Metric, Sia, Thom York, The Bravery, Civil Twilight, Grizzly Bear, and Vampire Weekend. Not too shabby for some Vampire movie!

I love the fusion of sexy guitar melodies and piano strung throughout this song, and when I listen to the lyrics, I imagine some hot chick that is able to hitchhike her way through the south nothing but her looks and her charm. Itâ€™s interesting how the lyrics for this song, and most other Black Keys songs for that matter, paint a picture of some strong, badass female (and it always makes me smile):

â€œAn innocent child in New Orleans

a simple girl from simple means

walked the rails

rode her thumb

she hitched a ride with the every one

The regular, sheâ€™d rearrange

the girl knew how to chop and change

chop and change

chop and change

chop and change

chop and change

Took a job workin late

jackin cars from out of state

she found no love in this town

so sheâ€™d never mess around

had no luck, but aint it strange

the girl knew how to chop and change

chop and change.â€

I was SUPER STOKED when The Black Keys played this song at Outside Lands this year. I knew ALL OF THE LYRICS and was belting them out like a ROCKSTAR. ğŸ˜‰

â€˜I Suppose I should say â€˜thanksâ€™ or some shitâ€™ is one of my favorite Gold Panda songs. DO ME A FAVOR and PLEASE LISTEN to the ENTIRE SONG. I feel like you are cheating yourself I you only listen for a few seconds in and press next, because this song takes a while to build up intensity. At ~1:27 youâ€™ll certainly get hooked, and then as you listen on further, the choppiness of the beat at ~2:03 and ~2:15 will make your EYES WIDEN. The indecisive keyboard â€œdanceâ€ at ~2:57 will have you bopping your head like a madman, and at ~3:24 youâ€™ll pretty much be HAVING A SEIZURE. Yeah, itâ€™s THAT GOOD. Iâ€™ll be seeing you at The Independent in San Francisco on October 23, Mr. Gold Panda. Canâ€™t wait. ğŸ™‚

â€˜Night Busâ€™ is an absolutely GORGEOUS acoustic track that I stumbled upon when listening to some Bombay Bicycle Club songs on YouTube. It turns out that Lucy Rose, the beautifully unique female voice behind this track, is also the female singer for Bombay Bicycle Club (one of my new favorite bands). Although Lucy only started gaining notoriety as the featured artist on the title track of their 2010 album, Flaws, she has actually been playing open mics in London since she was 18 yrs old. According to an interview with Lucy Rose performed by CLASHMUSIC.com, she has hopes of making an album â€œone day,â€ following up her debut single, â€˜Middle Of The Bedâ€™ (release Aug 8, 2011).

The first time I heard â€˜Night Bus,â€™ I literally listened to it 10 times in a row before I felt like I could move onto another song. It was just the perfect for a stressful day of lab analysis. Although I love the soothing entrance of the guitar, itâ€™s the gentle, sweet voice that follows which really strikes a chord with me. The â€œIâ€™m not aloneâ€¦She said, â€˜Iâ€™m not aloneâ€ verse just send chills down my spine every time. The one line that really stick out to me is: â€œSheâ€™s not phased by the darkness in her soulâ€¦And you barely catch a glimpse of herâ€¦cause sheâ€™s wrapped tightly, hiding in her clothes.â€ SOOOO GOOD. I also really like the verse:

â€œAnd theyâ€™re strangers, and theyâ€™re walking my way

and Iâ€™m talking to myself

Strangers, and theyâ€™re walking my way

and Iâ€™m talking to myself (her voice sound so pretty here)

And theyâ€™re strangers, and theyâ€™re walking my way

and Iâ€™m talking to myself

Strangers, and theyâ€™re walking my way

and Iâ€™m talking to myself.â€

The textured, warm and overwhelmingly beautiful fusion of acoustic guitar and vocals in this song will forever make it my GO TO track for one of those rough days when Iâ€™m either stressed or upset and donâ€™tâ€™ want to feel â€œalone.â€ Thank you, Lucy Rose. ğŸ™‚

â€˜As Far as I Can Seeâ€™ is a song by Phantogram (name inspired by the optical illusion called phantogram), an American electronic rock duo from Saratoga Springs, New York, formed in 2007 and consisting of Josh Carter (vocals, guitars) and Sarah Barthel (vocals, keyboards). They write and record in a remote barn in upstate New York called Harmony Lodge, nearby Skidmore College (where fellow beat-experimenters Ratatat formed!). However, you would not expect this from their â€œstreet beat, psych popâ€ style music that has â€œlots of rhythms, swirling guitars, spacey keyboards, echoes, airy vocals.â€ In 2009, they signed with Barsuk Records (Death Cab for Cutie, Ra Ra Riot, etc.) Phantogram has played and toured with The Antlers, Beach House, Metric, Minus The Bear, Caribou, Zero 7, The xx, Ra Ra Riot, School of Seven Bells, Yeasayer, Brazilian Girls, and The Glitch Mob. They have also played several major North American festivals including Coachella, Sasquatch, Treasure Island, Lollapalooza, and Outside Lands (WHERE I RECENTLY SAW THEM!) Unfortunately, I only got there in enough time to see them perform their last song, but I got tickets to see them in Sacramento on November 1, so Iâ€™M HAPPY! My buddy Ken Diener got a really amazing live video (see my â€˜Live Footageâ€™ page) of them performing MY FAVORITE of their songs, â€˜Mouthful of Diamonds.â€™ (on my â€œYou Yes Youâ€ playlist on my â€˜Musical Treasureâ€˜ page)

Although I LOVE LOVE LOVE â€˜Mouthful of Diamonds,â€™ I also really like â€˜As Far as I can Seeâ€™ and â€˜When Iâ€™m Smallâ€™ (soon to be on my September playlist). I really dig the beginning of â€œAs Far As I can See,â€ with the aggressive choppiness of it sampler sounds and hip-hop beats that seem to meld perfectly with Sarahâ€™s beautiful vocals. There are so many different layers of sounds (samplers, tapes, records, synths, drums, and both percussive and stringed instruments) that meld together to create beautiful, beat-driven dreamlike pop songs like this one. It also helps that aside from having a sexy voice, Sarah is also INCREDILBY HOT. (see photos below)

â€˜Shake Me Downâ€™ is one of my favorite songs by Cage the Elephant, who I saw live at 2010 Austin City Limits music festival. I love the unexpected drum entrance at ~0:27, and the associated lyrics:

â€œShake me down,

Not a lot of people left around,

Who knows now,

Softly laying on the ground, ooooh

Not a lot people left around, ooooh. Ooooh.â€

My favorite part of the song is at ~1:14 in with the accelerated drum and the badass lyrics that in the end leave you with a hopeful message:

â€œIn my past, bittersweet,

Thereâ€™s no love between the sheets,

Taste the blood, broken dreams,

Lonely times indeed,

With eyes cast down,

Fixed upon the ground,

Eyes cast downâ€¦.

Iâ€™ll keep my eyes fixed on THE SUN.â€
